content.description:
The diagram above shows an electrochemical cell that consists of a zinc can containing an aqueous paste of <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>MnO</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> powder and an electrolyte that contains <math alttext="N H 4 C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. An inert carbon electrode is in contact with <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> paste. The balanced chemical equation for the overall reaction that occurs as the cell operates is shown below.

<math alttext="Z n plus 2 M n O 2, plus 2 H 2 O, react to produce Z n with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 M n O, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, plus 2 O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>Zn</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mtext> MnO</mtext> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mtext> H</mtext> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>→</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>Zn</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mtext> MnO</mtext> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mtext>OH</mtext> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <msup> <mrow> <mtext> OH</mtext> </mrow> <mo>−</mo> </msup> </mrow> </semantics> </math>

<math alttext="E naught sub cell, equals positive 1.58 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1.58</mn><mtext> V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Reduction Half Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="M n O 2, plus H 2 O, plus one electron, react to produce M n O, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, plus O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>MnO</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O +</mtext> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mtext>MnO(OH)</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="question mark" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge, plus 2 electrons, react to produce Z n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.76" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.76</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: A. Using the information in the table of reduction potentials, calculate the value of the standard reduction potential, <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, for <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: A. Using the information in the table of reduction potentials, calculate the value of the standard reduction potential, <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, for <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

B. A commercially available <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>D</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> cell is typically able to provide a current of <math alttext="0.200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ampere for <math alttext="20.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours. Assuming that <math alttext="Zn" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>Zn</mtext> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGAbGaaeOBaa aa@3ACC@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> is the reactant in excess, calculate the minimum number of moles of <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that are used in the <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell as it provides the current.

C. The chemical reaction that occurs in small <math alttext="double A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells is the same as that on which <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells operate. A student claims that the cell potential of the larger <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells would have to be greater than the cell potential of the smaller <math alttext="double A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. Do you agree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
